Topic.Title: OUR BABY IS GROWING UP SOOO FAST................

Message.Msg: Cute, but I'm not sure if there's enough of a catalyst to push this up to $13 this week. This seems to be a level that most are fairly comfortable with until something else comes along to show that more improvement is taking place. With the MBIA and AIG lawsuits still hanging over them, and with the $8.5 billion mortgage settlement still unapproved, folks are going to play a waiting game. A break in any of these areas will then set the stage for the next leg up. That, or a lot of increased enthusiasm that earnings will continue to rise despite these other issues.

Message.Title: this week, 28 of april 13
Message.Msg: This week, 28 of april ‘13 Reflecting upon the Boston marathon tragedies, President Obama said, “We have seen humanity at its best”, specifically citing the first responders who ran towards, rather than away from the bomb sites. He also praised area residents who opened their homes to complete strangers. Later, during talk of the Washington correspondents’ dinner, he was praised for his “impeccable sense of timing” in humorous dialogue…and a possible post presidency career path was mentioned. But Syria also discussed. ABC’s Martha Raddatz spoke of clear evidence of use of sarin (poison gas), yet noted “no chain of custody” of it has been proven. GOP House member from Michigan, “Mike’ Rogers claimed evidence of its use during the past years. The Atlantic magazine’s Jeffrey Goldberg spoke of the need for that “clear evidence”, especially in view of the MWDs NOT found in Iraq. Goldberg also maintains “no one” is pushing for USA boots on the ground in Syria. Re the Boston “suspects”—there is need to determine when the older one was radicalized…his six months in Russia mentioned, but “what happened” there unknown. Goldberg noted, “one can be radicalized” in USA—the internet, etc. He also cited the role of “moderate” USA Muslims in dealing with radicalized members of their faith. “We love our country and we do our best”, the current president said re his predecessors, one assumes including himself in the “we’ as well. The sequester matter—called “colossal failure of leadership” by GOP House member from Fla. Democrat strategist Donna Brazile said the sequester has harmed many an ordinary citizen—meals on wheels cited. LA mayor, serving final term, feels that Congress is fixed on ideology to the detriment of the country. Past speaker “Newt” Gingrich wishes congress to deal with immigration “one piece at a time”. Mention of course of hundreds’ pages of bills passed, such as “Obama care” in which provisions are buried. Sponsors, Citgo and Shell, the latter

Topic.Title: OUR BABY IS GROWING UP SOOO FAST................

Message.Msg: Anything is possible, but if it were to drop I personally would consider that a greater buying opportunity. If you've noticed during this stock's long climb back, it has tended to consolidate at certain levels, bouncing around for awhile, even taking a few steps backward. Those that took advantage of those set backs were rewarded accordingly. The long term trend, at least in my opinion, is upward. It won't happen fast, and it definitely won't be in a straight line. We will see many ups and downs, and every time it does go down, the doom and gloomers will scream about how the stock is collapsing, and every time it goes up, the pollyanna's will scream about how it is flying to the moon. The reality is that we will continue to see what has been going on the past few months, with the trend continuing to move up. My opinion of course.

Message.Title: The Muzzie-in-Chief isn't concerned ..... he keeps sending arms to Egypt .....
Message.Msg: Newly-emerged video appears to show Egyptian police standing idly by - and even helping attackers during a deadly assault earlier this month on a Coptic cathedral where Christians were mourning five men killed in an earlier clash with Muslims. The video shot April 7 and first obtained by MidEast Christian News, shows a men shooting guns, wielding machetes and hurling stones and possibly Molotov cocktails as mourners carry caskets out of St. Mark’s Coptic Orthodox Cathedral in the Abbassia District of Cairo as uniformed police watch, unmoving. At one point, a police officer appears to help a gunman take aim at a courtyard full of mourners who had spilled out of the church. The attack left two Copts dead and another 84 people injured, including 11 police officers. When it was over, the only arrests made were of four Copts. Christians, who were already outraged over a three-day attack that began April 4 attack in Khosous which saw the four men killed and homes, a nursery and a church burned, said the events show how elusive justice is for Christians, who make up about 10 percent of the nation's population.
